definition: The complete set of genetic material in an organism
example: The human genome contains approximately 3 billion base pairs

definition: The complete set of RNA transcripts produced by the genome
example: RNA-seq is used to analyze the transcriptome

definition: The entire set of proteins expressed by a genome or cell
example: Mass spectrometry helps identify proteins in the proteome

definition: The complete set of small-molecule metabolites in a biological sample
example: The metabolome reflects the physiological state of a cell

definition: Genetic material recovered directly from environmental samples
example: Shotgun sequencing is used for metagenome analysis

definition: The complete set of epigenetic modifications in an organism
example: The epigenome regulates gene expression without changing DNA sequence

definition: The complete lipid profile within a cell or organism
example: Lipidomics reveals membrane composition changes in disease

definition: The entire complement of glycans in an organism
example: The glycome plays crucial roles in cell recognition

definition: The process of determining the nucleotide order in DNA or RNA
The process of identifying and labeling features in a genome
example: Genome annotation predicts gene locations and functions

definition: The process by which genetic information is used to synthesize proteins
example: Gene expression varies between different cell types

definition: The computational process of reconstructing a genome from sequence reads
example: De novo assembly constructs genomes without a reference

definition: Arranging DNA or protein sequences to identify similarity regions
The evolutionary history and relationships among organisms
A contiguous stretch of DNA sequence assembled from overlapping reads
example: Assembly software generates contigs from short reads

definition: A larger DNA sequence formed by connecting contigs
example: Scaffolding uses paired-end reads to order contigs

definition: A piece of DNA or RNA that is amplified through PCR
A short DNA sequence used to identify samples or species
example: DNA barcoding enables rapid species identification

definition: The average number of reads representing a given nucleotide
example: 30× coverage means each base is sequenced 30 times on average

definition: The total number of reads at a specific genomic position
example: Sequencing depth affects variant calling accuracy

definition: A genomic locus that differs between individuals
example: Single nucleotide variants are the most common type

definition: The occurrence of multiple forms of a gene in a population
Alternative forms of a gene at the same locus
example: Humans inherit one allele from each parent

definition: The genetic makeup of an organism
example: Genotyping reveals genetic variations in populations

definition: The observable characteristics of an organism
A group of genes inherited together from a single parent
The preservation of gene order on chromosomes across species
example: Synteny analysis identifies conserved genomic regions

definition: Genes in different species evolved from a common ancestor
Genes related by duplication within a genome
Similarity due to shared ancestry
A three-nucleotide sequence encoding an amino acid
example: The start codon AUG codes for methionine

definition: A coding sequence in a gene that is expressed
example: Exons are spliced together to form mature mRNA

definition: A non-coding sequence removed during RNA splicing
example: Introns are transcribed but not translated

definition: A cluster of genes under control of a single promoter
example: The lac operon regulates lactose metabolism in bacteria

definition: A DNA region where transcription is initiated
example: Promoters bind RNA polymerase to start transcription

definition: A DNA region that increases gene transcription
example: Enhancers can act over long distances

definition: A DNA region that decreases gene transcription
A small circular DNA molecule in bacteria
example: Plasmids are used as vectors in genetic engineering

definition: A DNA molecule used to transfer genetic material
A genetically identical copy
example: Cloning produces multiple copies of a DNA fragment

definition: A short DNA sequence initiating replication or amplification
example: PCR primers flank the target DNA region

definition: An enzyme that synthesizes polynucleotide chains
An enzyme that joins DNA fragments
example: DNA ligase seals nicks in the DNA backbone

definition: An enzyme that cleaves nucleic acids
example: Restriction endonucleases cut DNA at specific sites

definition: The process of cutting DNA at specific sequences
example: Restriction mapping creates a physical map of DNA

definition: An enzyme that cuts within a nucleic acid strand
example: CRISPR uses Cas9 endonuclease for genome editing

definition: An enzyme that removes nucleotides from the end of DNA
An enzyme that unwinds the DNA double helix
example: Helicase activity is essential for DNA replication

definition: An enzyme that relieves DNA supercoiling
The addition of methyl groups to DNA
The addition of acetyl groups to histones
The complex of DNA and proteins in the nucleus
A protein around which DNA wraps in eukaryotes
The basic unit of chromatin packaging
example: Each nucleosome contains 147 base pairs of DNA

definition: The synthesis of RNA from a DNA template
example: Transcription is the first step of gene expression

definition: The synthesis of protein from mRNA
A cellular structure that synthesizes proteins
example: Ribosomes read mRNA codons to build proteins

definition: RNA carrying genetic information from DNA to ribosomes
RNA that delivers amino acids during translation
example: tRNA molecules have anticodons complementary to mRNA

definition: RNA component of ribosomes
example: rRNA makes up the catalytic core of ribosomes

definition: Small regulatory RNA molecules
RNA transcripts over 200 nucleotides that don't code for proteins
phonetic: lɒŋ nɒn ˈkəʊdɪŋ ɑːr en eɪ

definition: The removal of introns from pre-mRNA
Addition of adenine nucleotides to mRNA
Addition of a modified guanine to mRNA 5' end
example: 5' capping stabilizes mRNA and aids translation

definition: The breakdown of biomolecules
example: RNA degradation regulates gene expression levels

definition: The time required for half of a molecule to degrade
example: mRNA half-life varies from minutes to hours

definition: The rate of molecule synthesis and degradation
A series of biochemical reactions
example: Metabolic pathways convert substrates to products

definition: The sum of chemical reactions in an organism
Biosynthetic pathways building complex molecules
Degradative pathways breaking down molecules
A biological catalyst
The molecule upon which an enzyme acts
The molecule resulting from an enzymatic reaction
example: Reaction products may become substrates for other enzymes

definition: A non-protein molecule required for enzyme activity
example: Metal ions often serve as cofactors

definition: An organic cofactor
A tightly bound cofactor
example: Heme is a prosthetic group in hemoglobin

definition: A substance that increases reaction rate
A molecule that decreases enzyme activity
example: Competitive inhibitors compete with substrate binding

definition: A molecule that increases enzyme activity
Addition of phosphate groups to molecules
Addition of carbohydrate groups to proteins
example: Glycosylation affects protein folding and function

definition: Attachment of ubiquitin proteins
Modifications occurring after protein synthesis
The breakdown of proteins by enzymes
example: Proteolysis is involved in protein turnover

definition: An enzyme that cleaves peptide bonds
An enzyme that adds phosphate groups
example: Protein kinases are key signaling molecules

definition: An enzyme that removes phosphate groups
A short chain of amino acids
example: Peptides are building blocks of proteins

definition: A long chain of amino acids
A distinct functional unit within a protein
A short conserved sequence pattern
The three-dimensional structure of a molecule
The loss of protein structure
The process by which proteins attain structure
A protein assisting in folding of other proteins
The clumping of misfolded proteins
The study of molecular structure using crystals
Analysis using light-matter interactions
Separation technique based on molecular properties
Separation of molecules in an electric field
example: Gel electrophoresis separates DNA by size

definition: Transfer of molecules to a membrane for analysis
Isolation of proteins using antibodies
A protein that recognizes and binds antigens
example: Antibodies are used in many proteomics methods

definition: A molecule that triggers an immune response
The specific region of an antigen recognized by antibodies
example: Linear epitopes are continuous amino acid sequences

definition: The strength of molecular binding
example: High-affinity antibodies bind tightly to antigens

definition: The selectivity of molecular recognition
The ability to detect small amounts
example: High sensitivity methods detect low-abundance proteins

definition: The rate of sample processing
example: High-throughput sequencing analyzes millions of reads

definition: Simultaneous analysis of multiple samples or targets
Adjustment for technical variation
Technical variation between experimental batches
Repetition of experiments
A standard for comparison in experiments
Confirmation of results using independent methods
The ability to obtain consistent results
example: Reproducibility is essential for scientific rigor

definition: The presence of unwanted material in samples
Procedures ensuring data reliability
stress: Primary stress on first and second words

definition: An incorrect positive result
An incorrect negative result
The likelihood that a result is not due to chance
stress: Primary stress on second and third words

definition: A statistical relationship between variables
Statistical modeling of relationships
example: Linear regression predicts expression from genotype

definition: Grouping similar data points
Assignment of samples to categories
Simplification of high-dimensional data
example: PCA is a dimensionality reduction technique
stress: Primary stress on fourth and second words

definition: A linear combination of variables
stress: Primary stress on first and second words

definition: Study of interactions between entities
example: Protein interaction networks reveal cellular organization
